translated_text:
The War
World
Vladimir Putin, the Russian President and former spy who ordered the invasion of Ukraine
Lusa Agency
01 Mar 2022
09:01
0
Comments
Russian President Vladimir Putin caused disbelief when he invaded Ukraine, his biggest military action since the annexation of Crimea in 2014, despite never having hidden his ambition to restore Russia's power.
Ruler of the country since 2000 - alternately assuming the roles of President and Prime Minister - Putin, aged 69, is the longest-serving Kremlin leader since Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin, who died in 1953.
In 2020, a constitutional revision was approved in a controversial national referendum that gave Putin the possibility of remaining in power after his current fourth term, which ends in 2024. He will therefore be able to stay in the Kremlin until 2036.
A FORMER SPY
His critics see in him traces of the Soviet era that shaped his view of the world: Putin was a spy for the KGB - the sadly famous Soviet secret service agency - before embarking on a meteoric rise amid the chaos of the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Many of his close collaborators and friends are or were linked to the secret services.
Putin's political career began in the early 1990s, when he worked as a senior advisor to the mayor of Saint Petersburg Anatoly Sobchak, who had been his law professor at university.
In 1997, he entered the Kremlin as director of the Federal Security Service (FSB - successor to the KGB) and was quickly appointed prime minister.
On the last day of 1999, the then Russian President, Boris Yeltsin, resigned and appointed Putin as interim President.
He has been in power since then, although he had to occupy the position of prime minister between 2008 and 2012, because the Russian Constitution prohibited him, at the time, from running for a third consecutive presidential term.
He then returned to head the State after winning the 2012 elections with more than 66% of the votes, amid accusations of electoral fraud.
The Soviet pomp of military parades was restored, and portraits of Stalin, once banned, were once again displayed.
Even the Russian vaccine against Covid-19 was named Sputnik V, in reference to the Soviet probe Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite, placed into orbit in 1957.
Putin described the dismemberment of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) as "the greatest geopolitical catastrophe of the [20th] century" and frequently criticized the expansion of NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization) to Russia's borders from 1997 onwards.
GLACIAL RELATIONS WITH THE WEST
Previous tensions between Russia and Ukraine (not only the annexation of the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014, but the ongoing armed conflict since then in the pro-Russian separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine, which has claimed more than 14,000 lives in the last eight years) and Moscow's intervention in the Syrian civil war in support of President Bashar al-Assad, had already revived Western suspicions of Putin's imperialist ambitions.
Relations have become as glacial as during the Cold War, with the exception of the period in office of US President Donald Trump, who openly expressed his admiration for his Russian counterpart.
Joe Biden, who succeeded him in the White House, described Putin as “a killer”.
THE IMAGE OF VIRILITY
Putin cultivates an image of virility, with his photos on horseback bare-chested and electoral maneuvers such as his entry into Chechnya on a fighter plane in 2000, or his appearance at a biker festival near the Black Sea in 2011.
But he also makes a point of showing a softer side in the Russian state press, appearing in images petting his dogs or helping to care for Siberian tigers, an endangered species.
A survey carried out in February 2021 by the Russian opinion research center Levada indicated that 48% of Russian citizens wanted Putin to remain President of the country after 2024.
This number may be envied by many Western political leaders, but it may also simply suggest that the population is not free to give another answer when asked, or that it simply sees Putin as a safe bet, having kept Russia relatively stable after the post-communist chaos of the 1990s.
In addition to restoring widespread national pride, Putin has allowed a middle class to emerge and prosper, despite Moscow continuing to control the economy and Russian poverty being a glaring reality.
DOMESTIC PROBLEMS
His popularity among older Russian citizens is clearly greater than among the younger population, who grew up with Putin in power and appear to be thirsty for change.
In January 2021, thousands of young Russians demonstrated across the country in support of Alexei Navalny, Putin's main opponent, who was immediately detained upon arriving in Russia, returning from Berlin, where he had been recovering from an assassination attempt with Novichok, a neurotoxic gas, which Western governments soon blamed on Putin's FSB.
Navalny gained notoriety for denouncing rampant corruption, calling Putin's United Russia a "party of crooks and thieves."
The demonstrations that followed were some of the largest Russia has seen in recent years, stifled by police repression that resulted in thousands of people being detained.
Currently in prison with health problems, Navalny, controversially convicted in an old case of embezzlement, is another reason why Putin's relations with the West are in bad shape.
In August 2020, Navalny narrowly survived poisoning with Novichok, a Russian military-made toxin also used to try to kill former Russian spy Serguei Skripal and his daughter Iulia in England in 2018.
Putin has denied any involvement in these and other attacks on prominent political opponents.
A HARD CHILDHOOD
Vladimir Putin grew up in a Leningrad communal housing neighborhood – now St. Petersburg – and fought with the neighborhood boys, who were often bigger and stronger. That's what led him to learn judo.
According to the Kremlin's website, Putin wanted to work in the Soviet secret services "even before finishing his studies."
"50 years ago, the streets of Leningrad taught me one rule: if a fight is inevitable, we must be the ones to throw the first punch," Putin declared in October 2015.
He used the crude language of a street fighter to defend his military offensive against separatist rebels in Chechnya, promising to eliminate them "even in the toilets".
That republic in the North Caucasus, mostly Muslim, was devastated by violent fighting between 1999 and 2000, which claimed thousands of civilian lives.
Georgia is another flashpoint for Putin: in 2008, Russian forces defeated the Georgian army and took control of two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
This conflict with Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili, then in favor of NATO, made it clear that Putin was ready to attack the pro-Western leaders of the former Soviet republics.
MULTI-MILLIONAIRE FRIENDS
Putin's inner circle constitutes an extraordinarily wealthy elite, and he himself is thought to possess an enormous fortune, despite keeping his family and financial affairs well shielded from publicity.
The Panama Papers leaks in 2016 revealed a shadowy network of offshore companies belonging to Putin's longtime friend, cellist Serguei Roldugin.
Putin and his wife, Lyudmila, divorced in 2013, after almost 30 years of marriage. She described him as a workaholic.
According to an investigation by the Reuters agency cited by the BBC, one of Putin's daughters, Katerina, holds a top administrative position at Moscow State University and participates in television 'rock'n'roll' dance competitions.
The eldest daughter, Maria, is a university professor of Medicine, specializing in Endocrinology.
THE LIBERALS AWAY
Putin's display of patriotism dominates Russian media, which distorts media coverage in his favor, to such an extent that it is difficult to calculate the dimensions of the opposition.
During his first two presidential terms, Putin benefited from significant revenues from oil and gas – Russia's main exports – and the standard of living for the majority of Russian citizens improved, but the price to be paid, in the opinion of many, was the erosion of Russia's young democracy.
Since the global financial crisis of 2008, Putin has been struggling with an anemic economy, hit by recession and, more recently, by the plummeting price of oil.
Russia has lost many foreign investors and billions of dollars in capital flight.
Putin's "reign" has been marked by conservative Russian nationalism, with strong echoes of tsarist absolutism, encouraged by the Orthodox Church.
Shortly after ascending to the Presidency, Putin began to sideline liberal figures, often replacing them with tougher allies or neutral figures considered mere sympathizers.
This is how Yeltsin's favorites like oligarchs Boris Berezovsky and Vladimir Gusinsky ended up becoming fugitives who now live in exile abroad.
The international community's concern about respect for human rights in Russia has grown over the years, following the arrest of oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovski, once one of the world's richest multimillionaires, and anti-Putin activists from the 'punk' band Pussy Riot.
Currently, as Russia invades Ukraine and Putin warns that Moscow's response will be "immediate and never seen" if the West tries to attack Russia, all eyes are on the Russian President to see what he will do next.
Vladimir Putin

title: Ucrânia . Rússia caminha para uma  recessão profunda , diz JPMorgan
original_title: Ucrânia. Rússia caminha para uma "recessão profunda", diz JPMorgan
translated_title: Ukraine. Russia heading for 'deep recession', says JPMorgan
original_text:
N
o documento, que a Efe teve acesso, a equipa de analistas norte-americanos especializada em mercados emergentes sublinha que a resposta do Ocidente "atingirá o alvo da economia russa, que agora parece caminhar para uma recessão profunda e a imposição de controlos de capital".
Os analistas estimam que a economia russa sofra uma contração de 20% no segundo trimestre, face ao anterior, e consideram que no conjunto do ano venha a reduzir-se em 3,5%, embora não descartem um número maior porque "os riscos são tendenciosos com força para o lado negativo".
Além disso, "acreditamos que o crescimento isolamento político e económico da Rússia restringirá o potencial crescimento nos próximos anos e reduzirá o crescimento da tendência para 1%, de 1,75% anteriormente", acrescentam.
Washington, em coordenação com os seus aliados, aumentou hoje a pressão com sanções que impedem o Banco Central da Rússia a usar as suas reservas de dólares no mundo e proíbem qualquer instituição financeira ou empresa norte-americana a fazer transações e operações com ele".
Os esforços dos aliados ocidentais estão agora focados na elaboração da lista de bancos russos que serão excluídos do sistema de comunicação interbancário internacional SWIFT, o que isolaria ainda mais a economia russa do sistema financeiro internacional.
O relatório da JPMorgan destaca que as sanções, que já congelaram 630.000 milhões de dólares (cerca de 559.000 milhões de euros, à taxa de câmbio atual) das reservas do Banco Central russo, procuram "infligir danos significativos à economia russa, mantendo o fluxo de exportações de petróleo e gás natural russos".
A questão imediata "é se os aliados ocidentais podem efetivamente delinear exceções para pagamentos de energia sob as sanções SWIFT", acrescentam os analistas, que advertem que Moscovo poderá interromper as suas exportações de energia em retaliação.
Também alertam que as tensões entre a Rússia e a Ucrânia "podem ter um efeito substancial nos preços de outras matérias-primas, como trigo e, mais importante, paládio, que é essencial para produzir semicondutores e onde a oferta é restrita nos últimos anos".
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já mataram mais de 350 civis, incluindo crianças, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de mais de 100 mil deslocados e quase 500 mil refugiados na Polónia, Hungria, Moldova e Roménia.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de a Rússia se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e a União Europeia e os Estados Unidos, entre outros, responderam com o envio de armas e munições para a Ucrânia e o reforço de sanções para isolar ainda mais Moscovo.

translated_text:
N
In the document, which Efe had access to, the team of North American analysts specializing in emerging markets emphasizes that the West's response "will hit the target of the Russian economy, which now appears to be heading towards a deep recession and the imposition of capital controls".
Analysts estimate that the Russian economy will contract by 20% in the second quarter, compared to the previous one, and consider that it will contract by 3.5% for the year as a whole, although they do not rule out a higher number because "the risks are strongly biased towards the negative side".
Furthermore, "we believe that Russia's growing political and economic isolation will restrict potential growth in the coming years and reduce trend growth to 1% from 1.75% previously," they add.
Washington, in coordination with its allies, increased pressure today with sanctions that prevent the Central Bank of Russia from using its dollar reserves around the world and prohibit any financial institution or US company from carrying out transactions and operations with it."
The efforts of Western allies are now focused on drawing up the list of Russian banks that will be excluded from the SWIFT international interbank communication system, which would further isolate the Russian economy from the international financial system.
The JPMorgan report highlights that the sanctions, which have already frozen 630,000 million dollars (around 559,000 million euros, at the current exchange rate) of the Russian Central Bank's reserves, seek to "inflict significant damage on the Russian economy while maintaining the flow of Russian oil and natural gas exports."
The immediate question "is whether Western allies can effectively outline exceptions for energy payments under SWIFT sanctions," add the analysts, who warn that Moscow could halt its energy exports in retaliation.
They also warn that tensions between Russia and Ukraine "could have a substantial effect on the prices of other raw materials, such as wheat and, most importantly, palladium, which is essential for producing semiconductors and where supply has been tight in recent years."
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

title: Tenista ucraniana Elina Svitolina recusa - se a defrontar rival russa
original_title: Tenista ucraniana Elina Svitolina recusa-se a defrontar rival russa — DNOTICIAS.PT
translated_title: Ukrainian tennis player Elina Svitolina refuses to face Russian rival — DNOTICIAS.PT
original_text:
A Guerra
Desporto
Tenista ucraniana Elina Svitolina recusa-se a defrontar rival russa
Agência Lusa
28 fev 2022
21:48
0
Comentários
Foto EPA
Monterrey, México, 28 fev 2022 (Lusa) -- A melhor tenista ucraniana de todos os tempos, Elina Svitolina, garantiu hoje que não defrontará a russa Anastasia Potapova na terça-feira, no México, até as entidades reguladoras da modalidade clarificarem a posição sobre a invasão à Ucrânia.
"Espero que as nossas entidades (WTA, ITF e ATP) aceitem as recomendações do Comité Olímpico Internacional (COI) e forcem os atletas desses países a competir sob bandeira neutra e sem mostrarem qualquer tipo de símbolo dos seus países", escreveu Svitolina, nas redes sociais.
No WTA 250 de Monterrey, a 15.ª da hierarquia mundial tem pela frente Anastasia Potapova, a quem isenta de responsabilidades -- tal como aos outros competidores - pela invasão da Rússia ao seu país.
"Não culpo os atletas russos, eles não são culpados por aquilo que se está a passar no meu país. Aliás, o apoio dos atletas desses países tem sido fundamental e quero agradecer-lhes", frisou.
Os russos Daniil Medvedev, Andrey Rublev e Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova são alguns dos tenistas que já se manifestaram publicamente contra a guerra.
O COI aconselhou as diferentes federações desportivas a excluírem as equipas, seleções e atletas russos e bielorrussos de todos os eventos internacionais.
No ténis, tal como no ciclismo, os atletas só esporadicamente representam o seu país, pelo que se aguarda por uma clarificação das respetivas federações internacionais quanto a esta matéria.
A grande maioria dos tenistas ucranianos já tinha emitido hoje um comunicado, no qual pediam apoio das entidades e uma clarificação das suas posições, lamentando a falta de reação que ainda se verifica.
Marta Kostyuk e Lesia Tsurenko pediram mesmo, entre várias medidas, o cancelamento dos torneios planeados para se disputar na Rússia.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já mataram mais de 350 civis, incluindo crianças, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de mais de 100 mil deslocados e quase 500 mil refugiados na Polónia, Hungria, Moldova e Roménia.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de a Rússia se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e a União Europeia e os Estados Unidos, entre outros, responderam com o envio de armas e munições para a Ucrânia e o reforço de sanções para isolar ainda mais Moscovo.

translated_text:
The War
Sport
Ukrainian tennis player Elina Svitolina refuses to face Russian rival
Lusa Agency
Feb 28, 2022
21:48
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Monterrey, Mexico, February 28, 2022 (Lusa) -- The best Ukrainian tennis player of all time, Elina Svitolina, guaranteed today that she will not face Russian Anastasia Potapova on Tuesday, in Mexico, until the sport's regulatory bodies clarify their position on the invasion of Ukraine.
"I hope that our entities (WTA, ITF and ATP) accept the recommendations of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and force athletes from these countries to compete under a neutral flag and without showing any type of symbol of their countries", wrote Svitolina, on social media.
At the WTA 250 in Monterrey, the 15th in the world hierarchy faces Anastasia Potapova, who is exempt from responsibility - like the other competitors - for Russia's invasion of her country.
"I don't blame the Russian athletes, they are not to blame for what is happening in my country. In fact, the support of the athletes from those countries has been fundamental and I want to thank them", he stressed.
Russians Daniil Medvedev, Andrey Rublev and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova are some of the tennis players who have publicly spoken out against the war.
The IOC advised different sports federations to exclude Russian and Belarusian teams, national teams and athletes from all international events.
In tennis, as in cycling, athletes only sporadically represent their country, so clarification is awaited from the respective international federations on this matter.
The vast majority of Ukrainian tennis players had already issued a statement today, in which they asked for support from entities and a clarification of their positions, regretting the lack of reaction that still exists.
Marta Kostyuk and Lesia Tsurenko even asked, among several measures, for the cancellation of tournaments planned to be played in Russia.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

title: Nicolás Maduro telefonou a Vladimir Putin para expressar apoio à Rússia
original_title: Nicolás Maduro telefonou a Vladimir Putin para expressar apoio à Rússia
translated_title: Nicolás Maduro called Vladimir Putin to express support for Russia
original_text:
"N
uma conversa telefónica, o Presidente Nicolás Maduro expressou um 'forte apoio' à Rússia, condenou as ações desestabilizadoras dos EUA e da NATO e salientou a importância de combater a campanha de mentiras e desinformação lançada pelos países ocidentais", explica uma mensagem do Ministério dos Negócios Estrangeiros (MNE) russo, na rede social Twitter.
O telefonema teve lugar "por iniciativa da parte venezuelana" e, durante a conversação, segundo o MNE da Rússia "o Presidente Vladimir Putin e o Presidente Nicolás analisaram, por telefone, o desenvolvimento da parceria estratégica russo-venezuelana, assim como a implementação de projetos conjuntos".
"Ambos os líderes concordaram em manter contactos a vários níveis", concluiu.
Numa outra mensagem, o ministro dos Negócios Estrangeiros russo, Sergey Lavrov, refere que "a Rússia está comprometida com as suas obrigações em matéria de não proliferação de armas de destruição maciça e está a tomar todas as medidas necessárias para impedir que apareçam armas nucleares e tecnologias afins na Ucrânia".
Na sexta-feira, a Venezuela pediu uma resolução pacífica do conflito Rússia-Ucrânia, depois da ofensiva militar russa em várias localidades ucranianas, acusando a NATO e os Estados Unidos da América (EUA) de violarem os acordos existentes.
Caracas disse ainda condenar as sanções internacionais contra a Rússia, por afetarem os direitos humanos do povo russo, enquanto a oposição venezuelana criticou o apoio de Caracas à Rússia e as alegadas intenções russas de usar a Venezuela com fins bélicos para pressionar os EUA.
O Presidente Nicolás Maduro manifestou em 17 de fevereiro apoio à Rússia perante as ameaças ocidentais.
"A Rússia conta com todo o apoio da República Bolivariana da Venezuela na luta que está a travar para dissipar as ameaças da NATO [Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte] e do mundo ocidental. A Rússia conta com todo o apoio para dissipar todas as ameaças e para que continue a ser um território de paz", disse Maduro em Caracas, durante uma visita do vice-primeiro-ministro da Rússia, Yuri Ivanovich Borisov.
"As relações entre a Rússia e a Venezuela cada vez adquirem maior nível estratégico, maior qualidade e profundidade no seu resultado e maior força histórica", adiantou.
Segundo a imprensa local as relações entre Caracas e Moscovo ntensificaram-se durante o mandato do falecido líder socialista Hugo Chávez (presidiu ao país entre 1999 e 2013), que em agosto de 2008 apoiou a Rússia durante a guerra com a Geórgia.
Durante o seu Governo, Hugo Chávez adquiriu armamento e equipamento militar à Rússia.
Atualmente, a Venezuela, governada por Nicolás Maduro, possui, entre outros, acordos de cooperação militar, cultural, energética e tecnológica, com a Rússia.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já mataram mais de 350 civis, incluindo crianças, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de mais de 100 mil deslocados e mais de 660 mil refugiados na Polónia, Hungria, Moldova e Roménia.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de a Rússia se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e a União Europeia e os Estados Unidos, entre outros, responderam com o envio de armas e munições para a Ucrânia e o reforço de sanções para isolar ainda mais Moscovo.

translated_text:
"N
In a telephone conversation, President Nicolás Maduro expressed 'strong support' for Russia, condemned the destabilizing actions of the USA and NATO and highlighted the importance of combating the campaign of lies and disinformation launched by Western countries", explains a message from the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MNE), on the social network Twitter.
The phone call took place "at the initiative of the Venezuelan side" and, during the conversation, according to the Russian MNE "President Vladimir Putin and President Nicolás analyzed, by telephone, the development of the Russian-Venezuelan strategic partnership, as well as the implementation of joint projects".
"Both leaders agreed to maintain contacts at various levels", he concluded.
In another message, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov states that "Russia is committed to its obligations regarding the non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and is taking all necessary measures to prevent nuclear weapons and related technologies from appearing in Ukraine."
On Friday, Venezuela called for a peaceful resolution of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, after the Russian military offensive in several Ukrainian locations, accusing NATO and the United States of America (USA) of violating existing agreements.
Caracas also said it condemned international sanctions against Russia, as they affected the human rights of the Russian people, while the Venezuelan opposition criticized Caracas' support for Russia and Russia's alleged intentions to use Venezuela for military purposes to pressure the USA.
On February 17, President Nicolás Maduro expressed support for Russia in the face of Western threats.
"Russia has the full support of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the fight it is waging to dispel the threats from NATO [North Atlantic Treaty Organization] and the Western world. Russia has the full support to dispel all threats and so that it continues to be a territory of peace," said Maduro in Caracas, during a visit by Russia's Deputy Prime Minister, Yuri Ivanovich Borisov.
"Relations between Russia and Venezuela are increasingly acquiring a greater strategic level, greater quality and depth in their results and greater historical strength", he added.
According to the local press, relations between Caracas and Moscow intensified during the mandate of the late socialist leader Hugo Chávez (presided over the country between 1999 and 2013), who in August 2008 supported Russia during the war with Georgia.
During his government, Hugo Chávez acquired weapons and military equipment from Russia.
Currently, Venezuela, governed by Nicolás Maduro, has, among others, military, cultural, energy and technological cooperation agreements with Russia.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and more than 660,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

title: Barril de petróleo Brent abre a cair 1 , 59 %, abaixo dos 100 dólares
original_title: Barril de petróleo Brent abre a cair 1,59%, abaixo dos 100 dólares
translated_title: Brent oil barrel opens falling 1.59%, below 100 dollars
original_text:
Início
Guerra na Ucrânia
Barril de petróleo Brent abre a cair 1,59%, abaixo dos 100 dólares
A cotação do barril de petróleo Brent para entrega em abril abriu hoje a cair 1,59% no mercado de futuros de Londres, após ter atingido na segunda-feira um novo máximo desde setembro de 2014.
Produção de petróleo.
© Rodger BOSCH / AFP
Dinheiro Vivo/Lusa
01 Março, 2022 • 09:16
Partilhar
este artigo
Facebook
Twitter
WhatsApp
E-mail
Partilhar
Comentar
O petróleo do Mar do Norte, de referência na Europa, abriu no International Petroleum Exchange nos 99,38 dólares, após ter fechado a sessão de segunda-feira a ser negociado a 100,99 dólares.
Desde que começou a invasão russa, na quinta-feira de madrugada, o Brent registou valores nunca vistos em sete anos, se bem que ainda não tenha atingido os de 2008, quando chegou a estar acima dos 132 dólares por barril.
A recente subida foi impulsionada pelo receio de que o agravamento da crise possa influenciar os fornecimentos vindos da Federação Russa, o segundo mais produtor mundial de petróleo e o principal exportador de gás.
A grande maioria dos países ocidentais, incluindo a UE, impôs sanções à Rússia e a oligarcas e empresários russos dos setores do petróleo, bancário e financeiro,
Fechar
Subscrever newsletter
Subscreva a nossa newsletter e tenha as notícias no seu e-mail todos os dias
Subscrever
Muito obrigado pelo seu registo.
O primeiro-ministro canadiano, Justin Trudeau, anunciou na segunda-feira que o Canadá vai banir "toda a importação de petróleo" russo, "uma indústria da qual o presidente Putin e os seus oligarcas se beneficiaram muito".
Num contexto de incerteza, a petrolífera britânica BP anunciou durante o fim de semana que está disposta a alienar a posição de 19,75%, que possui no conglomerado russo de energia Rosneft.
Calcula-se que um terço do petróleo e 40% do gás que a Europa importa venham da Federação Russa, com destaque para os oleodutos e gasodutos que passam por território ucraniano.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já mataram mais de 350 civis, incluindo crianças, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de mais de 100 mil deslocados e quase 500 mil refugiados na Polónia, Hungria, Moldova e Roménia.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de a Rússia se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e a União Europeia e os Estados Unidos, entre outros, responderam com o envio de armas e munições para a Ucrânia e o reforço de sanções para isolar ainda mais Moscovo.

translated_text:
Home
War in Ukraine
Brent oil barrel opens falling 1.59%, below 100 dollars
The price of a barrel of Brent oil for delivery in April opened today falling 1.59% on the London futures market, after having reached a new maximum since September 2014 on Monday.
Oil production.
© Rodger BOSCH / AFP
Dinheiro Vivo/Lusa
01 March, 2022 • 09:16
Share
this article
Facebook
Twitter
WhatsApp
Email
Share
Comment
North Sea oil, a benchmark in Europe, opened on the International Petroleum Exchange at $99.38, after closing Monday's session trading at $100.99.
Since the Russian invasion began, on Thursday morning, Brent has recorded values ​​never seen in seven years, although it has not yet reached those of 2008, when it reached above 132 dollars per barrel.
The recent rise was driven by fears that the worsening of the crisis could influence supplies from the Russian Federation, the world's second largest oil producer and main gas exporter.
The vast majority of Western countries, including the EU, have imposed sanctions on Russia and Russian oligarchs and businessmen in the oil, banking and financial sectors,
Close

Subscribe
Thank you very much for your registration.
Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on Monday that Canada will ban "all imports of Russian oil," "an industry from which President Putin and his oligarchs have greatly benefited."
In a context of uncertainty, British oil company BP announced over the weekend that it is willing to sell the 19.75% position it holds in Russian energy conglomerate Rosneft.
It is estimated that a third of the oil and 40% of the gas that Europe imports come from the Russian Federation, with emphasis on oil and gas pipelines that pass through Ukrainian territory.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and almost 500,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

The President of Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, called his counterpart Vladimir Putin today to express "strong support" for him, six days after Russia militarily invaded neighboring Ukraine, the Moscow Government reported.
"In a telephone conversation, President Nicolás Maduro expressed 'strong support' for Russia, condemned the destabilizing actions of the USA and NATO and highlighted the importance of combating the campaign of lies and disinformation launched by Western countries", explains a message from the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MNE), on the social network Twitter.
The phone call took place "at the initiative of the Venezuelan side" and, during the conversation, according to the Russian MNE "President Vladimir Putin and President Nicolás analyzed, by telephone, the development of the Russian-Venezuelan strategic partnership, as well as the implementation of joint projects".
"Both leaders agreed to maintain contacts at various levels", he concluded.
In another message, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov states that "Russia is committed to its obligations regarding the non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and is taking all necessary measures to prevent nuclear weapons and related technologies from appearing in Ukraine."
On Friday, Venezuela called for a peaceful resolution of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, after the Russian military offensive in several Ukrainian locations, accusing NATO and the United States of America (USA) of violating existing agreements.
Caracas also said it condemned international sanctions against Russia, as they affected the human rights of the Russian people, while the Venezuelan opposition criticized Caracas' support for Russia and Russia's alleged intentions to use Venezuela for military purposes to pressure the USA.
On February 17, President Nicolás Maduro expressed support for Russia in the face of Western threats.
"Russia has the full support of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the fight it is waging to dispel the threats from NATO [North Atlantic Treaty Organization] and the Western world. Russia has the full support to dispel all threats and so that it continues to be a territory of peace," said Maduro in Caracas, during a visit by Russia's Deputy Prime Minister, Yuri Ivanovich Borisov.
"Relations between Russia and Venezuela are increasingly acquiring a greater strategic level, greater quality and depth in their results and greater historical strength", he added.
According to the local press, relations between Caracas and Moscow intensified during the mandate of the late socialist leader Hugo Chávez (presided over the country between 1999 and 2013), who in August 2008 supported Russia during the war with Georgia.
During his government, Hugo Chávez acquired weapons and military equipment from Russia.
Currently, Venezuela, governed by Nicolás Maduro, has, among others, military, cultural, energy and technological cooperation agreements with Russia.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and more than 660,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.

title: Bruxelas saúda boicote da Netflix à Rússia e pede apoio contra propaganda
original_title: Bruxelas saúda boicote da Netflix à Rússia e pede apoio contra propaganda
translated_title: Brussels welcomes Netflix boycott of Russia and calls for support against propaganda
original_text:
N
uma reunião hoje realizada por videoconferência, Thierry Breton e Reed Hastings discutiram "a agressão militar em curso na Ucrânia e a necessidade de combater a desinformação patrocinada pelo Estado russo", informou o gabinete do comissário europeu, numa nota enviada à Lusa.
Citado pelo comunicado, Thierry Breton elogia "os planos" da empresa 'gigante' de transmissão por 'streaming' de "não incluir 20 canais apoiados pelo Estado russo".
"Reguladores dos meios de comunicação, operadores de telecomunicações, serviços de 'streaming' e plataformas 'online' devem desempenhar o seu papel no combate à propaganda de guerra do Kremlin [Presidência russa]", salienta o responsável pela tutela.
"Não podemos deixar qualquer pedra solta na luta contra a desinformação e a ação hostil apoiadas pelo Estado russo", adianta Thierry Breton.
A posição surge depois de, na segunda-feira, a Netflix ter anunciado que não vai cumprir a nova lei audiovisual da Rússia, que exigia à plataforma incluir cerca de 20 canais públicos para operar no país.
A legislação, prevista para entrar em vigor hoje, exige que a Netflix e outros serviços audiovisuais transmitam conteúdos de meios de comunicação social associados ao Kremlin, tais como o Canal Um, a rede de entretenimento NTV e o Canal da Igreja Ortodoxa.
O anúncio da Netflix aconteceu depois de a empresa tecnológica Meta também informar que irá restringir o acesso às redes sociais - que incluem Facebook, Instagram e WhatsApp - ao canal RT e à agência Sputnik, meios de comunicação social controlados pelo Governo russo, a pedido da UE.
Na conversa com Thierry Breton, o presidente executivo da 'gigante' tecnológica confirmou que "a Netflix não vai cumprir as novas obrigações russas".
Este encontro por videoconferência aconteceu no âmbito dos diálogos que a Comissão Europeia está a realizar com líderes da indústria para intensificar os esforços para contrariar a propaganda russa.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já mataram mais de 350 civis, incluindo crianças, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de mais de 100 mil deslocados e mais de 660 mil refugiados na Polónia, Hungria, Moldova e Roménia.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de a Rússia se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e a União Europeia e os Estados Unidos, entre outros, responderam com o envio de armas e munições para a Ucrânia e o reforço de sanções para isolar ainda mais Moscovo.

Disney junta-se à Netflix e Warner Bros. no boicote à Rússia

translated_text:
N
In a meeting held today via videoconference, Thierry Breton and Reed Hastings discussed "the ongoing military aggression in Ukraine and the need to combat disinformation sponsored by the Russian State", said the European Commissioner's office, in a note sent to Lusa.
Quoted in the statement, Thierry Breton praises "the plans" of the 'giant' streaming company to "not include 20 channels supported by the Russian State".
"Media regulators, telecommunications operators, streaming services and online platforms must play their role in combating the Kremlin's [Russian Presidency's] war propaganda", emphasizes the person responsible for supervision.
"We cannot leave any stone unturned in the fight against disinformation and hostile action supported by the Russian State", says Thierry Breton.
The position comes after, on Monday, Netflix announced that it will not comply with Russia's new audiovisual law, which required the platform to include around 20 public channels to operate in the country.
The legislation, set to come into force today, requires Netflix and other audiovisual services to broadcast content from Kremlin-associated media outlets such as Channel One, the NTV entertainment network and the Orthodox Church Channel.
Netflix's announcement came after the technology company Meta also announced that it will restrict access to social networks - which include Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp - to the RT channel and the Sputnik agency, social media outlets controlled by the Russian Government, at the request of the EU.
In the conversation with Thierry Breton, the executive president of the technological 'giant' confirmed that "Netflix will not comply with the new Russian obligations".
This video conference meeting took place as part of the dialogues that the European Commission is holding with industry leaders to intensify efforts to counter Russian propaganda.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already killed more than 350 civilians, including children, according to Kiev. The UN reported more than 100,000 displaced people and more than 660,000 refugees in Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and the European Union and the United States, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.
